modules.comments:
Main API for building type-safe state machines.

This module provides the core functions for creating state machine update
functions from type-level specifications.
```

children.comments:
Returns to the specified state.

For states with payloads:
```purescript
return @"StateName" { field: value }
```

For states with empty payloads:
```purescript
return @"StateName"
```
children.title: return

declarations.comments:
Type class for returning to a state in a transition handler.

Used with `return @"StateName"` to specify the target state after a transition.
declarations.title: Return

children.comments:
Returns to the specified state via a guard condition.

For states with payloads:
```purescript
returnVia @"GuardName" @"StateName" { field: value }
```

For states with empty payloads:
```purescript
returnVia @"GuardName" @"StateName"
```
children.title: returnVia

declarations.comments:
Type class for returning to a state via a guard condition.

Used with `returnVia @"GuardName" @"StateName"` to specify a conditional
transition with a guard.
declarations.title: ReturnVia

declarations.comments:
Creates a pure match handler for a state transition.

The handler function receives the current state and message, and returns
the new state. Use `matchM` for monadic handlers.

Example:
```purescript
match @"DoorOpen" @"Close" \_ _ -> return @"DoorClosed"
```
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
Creates a monadic match handler for a state transition.

The handler function receives the current state and message, and returns
the new state in a monadic context. Use `match` for pure handlers.

Example:
```purescript
matchM @"DoorOpen" @"Close" \_ _ -> do
  Console.log "Closing door"
  pure $ return @"DoorClosed"
```
declarations.title: matchM

declarations.comments:
Creates a pure update function.

Returns `state`, silently returning the unchanged state on illegal
transitions. Use `mkUpdateEither` if you need error handling.

Example:
```purescript
update :: State -> Msg -> State
update = mkUpdate @MyTransit ...
```
declarations.title: mkUpdate

declarations.comments:
Creates a monadic update function.

Returns `m state`, silently returning the unchanged state on illegal
transitions. Use `mkUpdateEitherM` if you need error handling.

Example:
```purescript
update :: State -> Msg -> Effect State
update = mkUpdateM @MyTransit ...
```
declarations.title: mkUpdateM

declarations.comments:
Creates a pure update function with error handling.

Returns `Maybe state`, returning `Nothing` for illegal transition requests.

Example:
```purescript
update :: State -> Msg -> Maybe State
update = mkUpdateEither @MyTransit ...
```
declarations.title: mkUpdateMaybe

declarations.comments:
Creates a monadic update function with error handling.

Returns `m (Maybe state)`, returning `Nothing` for illegal transition requests.

Example:
```purescript
update :: State -> Msg -> Effect (Maybe State)
update = mkUpdateEitherM @MyTransit ...
```
declarations.title: mkUpdateMaybeM

modules.name: Transit

declarations.comments: Wrapper for return values via a guard condition.
declarations.title: ViaGuard

declarations.comments: A transit core containing all matches (transitions) in a state machine.
declarations.title: TransitCore

declarations.comments: Type alias for state names (runtime).
declarations.title: StateName

declarations.comments: Type alias for message names (runtime).
declarations.title: MsgName

declarations.comments:
A match represents a transition from a state triggered by a message.

- First `StateName`: Source state name
- Second `MsgName`: Message name
- `Array Return`: Possible return states (may include guards)
declarations.title: Match

declarations.comments: Type alias for guard names (runtime).
declarations.title: GuardName

declarations.comments:
Extracts all unique state names from a transit core.

Returns all states that appear as either source states or target states
in any match, with duplicates removed.
declarations.title: getStateNames

declarations.comments:
Gets all matches (transitions) that originate from a given state.

Returns an array of all matches where the source state matches the
provided state name.
declarations.title: getMatchesForState

declarations.comments:
Base type for transit specifications (empty specification).

Start all transit specifications with `Transit`, then add matches using `:*`.

Example:
```purescript
type MyTransit =
  Transit
    :* ("State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2")
    :* ("State2" :@ "Msg2" >| "State3")
```
declarations.title: Transit

declarations.comments:
Internal type for adding an input (bidirectional edge).
Used with the `|<` operator.
declarations.title: AddIn

declarations.comments:
Type class that converts DSL match expressions to match specifications.

Handles conversion of state-message combinations and return states
into the underlying match type-level representation.
declarations.title: ToMatch

declarations.comments:
Type class that converts DSL return expressions to return specifications.

Handles conversion of state names and guard conditions into the
underlying return type-level representation.
declarations.title: ToReturn

declarations.comments:
Type class that converts DSL expressions to transit core specifications.

This class is used internally to transform the DSL syntax into the
underlying transit core type-level representation.
declarations.title: ToTransitCore

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for creating bidirectional edges.

Example: `"State1" |< "Msg" >| "State2"` creates edges in both directions.
declarations.title: type (|<)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for adding return states to a match.

Example: `"State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2" >| "State3"`
declarations.title: type (>|)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for combining a state with a message.

Example: `"State1" :@ "Msg1"`
declarations.title: type (:@)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for adding guard conditions to returns.

Example: `"guard" :? "State2"`
declarations.title: type (:?)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for adding matches to a transit specification.

Right-associative, allowing `Transit` to appear first for clean indentation.

Example: `Transit :* ("State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2")`
declarations.title: type (:*)

declarations.comments:
Graph representation of a state machine.

Nodes represent states, and edges represent transitions with their
associated messages and optional guard conditions.
declarations.title: StateGraph

declarations.comments:
Converts a transit core specification into a graph representation.

Each match in the transit core becomes one or more edges in the graph,
with each return state creating a separate edge. Guard conditions are
preserved in the edge labels.
declarations.title: mkStateGraph

modules.comments: Type classes for checking and expanding partial return types to full state types.

declarations.comments:
Checks and expands return types by removing `Ret` and `ViaGuard` wrappers from variant types.

The functional dependency `returns -> rowIn rowOut` ensures that given the
return list, both input and output row types are uniquely determined.

- `returns`: List of return type-level specifications
- `rowIn`: Input row type (with wrappers)
- `rowOut`: Output row type (without wrappers)
declarations.title: CheckReturn

declarations.comments:
A faster version of `checkReturn` that uses unsafe coercion.
This is useful for performance-critical code where code generated by the compiler is a bottleneck.
It is safe because we guarantee that the runtime representation of the handler function is the same as the type-level representation.
declarations.title: checkReturnFast

modules.name: Transit.Class.CheckReturn

modules.comments:
A type class for converting functions that take nested tuple arguments
into curried functions.

Example:
```purescript
f :: Int /\ String /\ Unit -> String
f (x /\ s /\ _) = s <> show x

curried :: Int -> String -> String
curried = curryN f
```

children.comments:
Base case: when the tuple is `Unit`, the function has no arguments
and we simply apply it to `unit`.
children.title: curryNUnit

children.comments:
Recursive case: for `arg /\ args`, we curry the first argument `arg`
and recursively curry the remaining arguments `args`.
children.title: curryNCons

declarations.comments:
Converts a function from nested tuple arguments to a curried function.

- `args`: The nested tuple type of arguments (must end with `Unit`)
- `result`: The return type of the function
- `curried`: The curried function type
declarations.title: CurryN

modules.name: Transit.Class.CurryN

modules.comments: Type class for building handler lookups from transit specifications.
modules.name: Transit.Class.MkHandlerLookup

modules.comments:
Core types and functions for transit specifications.

This module provides the foundational types for representing state machine
specifications at both the type level and value level. It includes:

- Type-level constructors for building transit specifications
- Runtime reflection of type-level specifications to values
- Core data types for matches, returns, and transit cores
- Utility functions for querying transit specifications

declarations.comments: Type alias for guard names (runtime).
declarations.title: GuardName

declarations.comments:
A match represents a transition from a state triggered by a message.

- First `StateName`: Source state name
- Second `MsgName`: Message name
- `Array Return`: Possible return states (may include guards)
declarations.title: Match

declarations.comments: Type for match implementations in the update function builder.
declarations.title: MatchImpl

declarations.comments: Type-level representation of a match (state, message, returns).
declarations.title: MatchTL

declarations.comments: Constructs a type-level match from a state name, message name, and list of returns.
declarations.title: MkMatchTL

declarations.comments: Constructs a type-level return to a state (no guard).
declarations.title: MkReturnTL

declarations.comments: Constructs a type-level return via a guard to a state.
declarations.title: MkReturnViaTL

declarations.comments: Constructs a type-level transit core from a list of matches.
declarations.title: MkTransitCoreTL

declarations.comments: Type alias for message names (runtime).
declarations.title: MsgName

declarations.comments:
A return specification indicating the next state after a transition.

- `Return stateName`: Direct transition to a state
- `ReturnVia guardName stateName`: Conditional transition via a guard
declarations.title: Return

declarations.comments: Wrapper for return values via a guard condition.
declarations.title: ViaGuard

declarations.comments: Type-level representation of a return specification.
declarations.title: ReturnTL

declarations.comments: Type alias for state names (runtime).
declarations.title: StateName

declarations.comments: A transit core containing all matches (transitions) in a state machine.
declarations.title: TransitCore

declarations.comments: Type-level representation of a transit core specification.
declarations.title: TransitCoreTL

declarations.comments: Type class that identifies a type as a valid transit specification.
declarations.title: IsTransitSpec

declarations.comments:
Gets all matches (transitions) that originate from a given state.

Returns an array of all matches where the source state matches the
provided state name.
declarations.title: getMatchesForState

declarations.comments:
Extracts all unique state names from a transit core.

Returns all states that appear as either source states or target states
in any match, with duplicates removed.
declarations.title: getStateNames

modules.name: Transit.Core

modules.comments:
Domain-Specific Language (DSL) for building type-level transit specifications.

This module provides a type-level DSL for constructing state machine
specifications in a declarative way. The DSL uses infix operators to create
readable specifications that are automatically converted to transit cores.

## Basic Usage

```purescript
type MyTransit =
  Transit
    :* ("State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2")
    :* ("State2" :@ "Msg2" >| "State1")
```

## Operators

- `:*` - Add a match/transition to the specification
- `:@` - Combine state and message (e.g., `"State1" :@ "Msg1"`)
- `>|` - Add return state(s) to a match
- `|<` - Create bidirectional edge (e.g., `"State1" |< "Msg" >| "State2"`)
- `:?` - Add guard condition to a return (e.g., `"guard" :? "State2"`)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for adding matches to a transit specification.

Right-associative, allowing `Transit` to appear first for clean indentation.

Example: `Transit :* ("State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2")`
declarations.title: type (:*)

children.comments: Allows DSL specifications to be reflected to runtime TransitCore values.
children.title: <anonymous>

children.comments: Transit specification with matches added via `:*`.
children.title: <anonymous>

Used with the `:*` operator.

declarations.title: type (:?)

declarations.title: type (:@)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for adding return states to a match.

Example: `"State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2" >| "State3"`
declarations.title: type (>|)

declarations.comments:
Infix operator for creating bidirectional edges.

Example: `"State1" |< "Msg" >| "State2"` creates edges in both directions.
declarations.title: type (|<)

declarations.title: ToTransitCore

declarations.comments:
Type class that converts DSL match expressions to match specifications.

Handles conversion of state-message combinations and return states

declarations.title: ToMatch

Type class that converts DSL return expressions to return specifications.

Handles conversion of state names and guard conditions into the

declarations.title: ToReturn

declarations.comments:
Base type for transit specifications (empty specification).

Start all transit specifications with `Transit`, then add matches using `:*`.

Example:
```purescript
type MyTransit =
  Transit
    :* ("State1" :@ "Msg1" >| "State2")
    :* ("State2" :@ "Msg2" >| "State3")
```

modules.comments:
Data types and functions for generating Graphviz DOT language output.

This module provides a type-safe way to construct DOT language graphs
for visualization with Graphviz.

declarations.comments: Graph attribute (name-value pair).
declarations.title: Attr

declarations.comments: Graph edge from one node to another with attributes.
declarations.title: Edge

declarations.comments: Global graph attributes.
declarations.title: GlobalAttrs

declarations.comments: Complete Graphviz directed graph.
declarations.title: GraphvizGraph

declarations.comments: Graph node with optional raw attributes and attribute list.
declarations.title: Node

declarations.comments: Raw DOT language string (for custom attributes).
declarations.title: Raw

declarations.comments: Section of a DOT graph (node, edge, or global attributes).
declarations.title: Section

declarations.comments: Attribute value types.
declarations.title: Value

declarations.comments: Type class for converting values to DOT language string representation.
declarations.title: ToDotStr

modules.name: Transit.Data.DotLang

modules.comments:
General purpose graph data structure for representing directed graphs with labeled edges.

This module provides a simple graph representation where:
- Edges are labeled (each edge has an associated label value)
- Nodes are values themselves
- Supports directed edges, cycles, and multiple edges between nodes

declarations.comments:
An edge in the graph connecting two nodes with a label.

- `edgeLabel`: The type of edge labels
- `node`: The type of node values
declarations.title: Edge

declarations.comments:
A directed graph that supports cycles and multiple edges.

Supports:
- Directed edges (fromNode -> toNode)
- Cycles (paths that return to a node, possibly through intermediate nodes)
- Multiple edges (same nodes can be connected by different edges)
declarations.title: Graph

declarations.comments: Creates a graph from a set of edges.
declarations.title: fromEdges

declarations.comments: Gets all incoming edges to a given node.
declarations.title: getIncomingEdges

declarations.comments: Extracts all unique nodes from the graph.
declarations.title: getNodes

declarations.comments: Gets all outgoing edges from a given node.
declarations.title: getOutgoingEdges

declarations.comments: Checks if an edge exists in the graph.
declarations.title: hasEdge

declarations.comments: Extracts all edges from a graph.
declarations.title: getEdges

declarations.comments: Maps over both edge label and node types in the graph.
declarations.title: mapGraph

declarations.comments:
Checks if the graph is undirected (all edges have symmetric counterparts).

A graph is considered undirected if for every edge from A to B,
there exists an edge from B to A with the same edge label.
declarations.title: isUndirected

Data types and functions for building HTML structures.

This module provides a simple, type-safe way to construct HTML nodes
and convert them to HTML strings. It's primarily used for generating
transition tables and other HTML output.

declarations.comments: Creates a table element.

declarations.comments: Creates a tbody element.

declarations.comments: Creates a th (table header) element.

declarations.comments: Creates a thead element.

modules.comments:
Color themes and harmonies for visualization generators.

This module provides color themes and color harmonies for use in
visualization generators (e.g., Graphviz). Themes define overall
color schemes, while color harmonies define coordinated colors
for nodes and edges in graphs.

declarations.comments: A set of coordinated colors for nodes and edges in a graph.
declarations.title: ColorHarmony

declarations.comments: A complete color theme for graph visualization.
declarations.title: Theme

declarations.comments: Gets a color harmony from a theme by index (cycles through available harmonies).
declarations.title: getColorHarmony

declarations.comments: Dark theme with colorful harmonies.
declarations.title: themeHarmonyDark

declarations.comments: Light theme with colorful harmonies.
declarations.title: themeHarmonyLight

declarations.comments: Dark theme with high contrast (white and black).

declarations.comments: Light theme with high contrast (black and white).

declarations.comments: Dark theme with gradient-style colors.
declarations.title: themeGradientDark

declarations.comments: Light theme with gradient-style colors.
declarations.title: themeGradientLight

Contains the message that triggers the transition and an optional
guard condition name.

associated messages and optional guard conditions.

Each match in the transit core becomes one or more edges in the graph,
with each return state creating a separate edge. Guard conditions are

modules.name: Transit.StateGraph

modules.comments:
Convenience utilities for creating Variant values.

This module provides a type-safe way to create Variant values using
type application, eliminating the need for Proxy values and allowing
empty record arguments to be omitted.

## Usage

For variants with empty payloads (empty record):
```purescript
v @"DoorOpen" :: State
```

For variants with non-empty payloads:
```purescript
v @"DoorLocked" { activePin: "1234" } :: State
```

children.comments:
Creates a Variant value by injecting a value into the specified variant label.

For variants with non-empty payloads, the payload must be provided:
```purescript
v @"Label" payload :: Variant (label :: PayloadType | r)
```

For variants with empty payloads (empty record), the payload
can be omitted:
```purescript
v @"Label" :: Variant (label :: {} | r)
```
children.title: v

children.comments:
Instance for variants with non-empty payloads.
Requires the payload to be provided as an argument.
children.title: <anonymous>

declarations.comments:
Type class for injecting values into Variants using type application.

The `v` function provides a convenient way to create Variant values
without needing Proxy values. It automatically handles both empty
and non-empty payloads.
declarations.title: Inj

modules.name: Transit.VariantUtils
